sub_topic: Show that every group of order 10 is isomorphic to either the cyclic group C10, the dihedral group D5, or the non-abelian group of order 10.
message_1:
Using group theory and the given subtopic, prove that the group G of order 10 defined by the Cayley table below is isomorphic to the non-abelian group of order 10. 

$$\begin{array}{|c|c|c|c|c|c|c|c|c|c|} \hline e & a & b & c & d & f & g & h & i & j \\ \hline a & e & f & g & h & b & c & d & j & i \\ \hline b & g & e & h & f & i & j & a & c & d \\ \hline c & f & h & e & g & j & i & b & d & a \\ \hline d & h & g & f & e & a & d & c & i & j \\ \hline f & b & i & j & a & e & h & g & d & c \\ \hline g & c & j & i & d & h & e & f & b & a \\ \hline h & d & a & b & c & g & f & e & j & i \\ \hline i & j & d & c & b & f & g & h & e & a \\ \hline j & i & c & d & a & g & h & f & b & e \\ \hline \end{array}$$

Note: You may assume the properties of groups and subgroups, and the orders of elements at any point in your proof.
message_2:
To prove that the given group G is isomorphic to the non-abelian group of order 10, we will first identify the structure of the non-abelian group of order 10 and then show that G has the same structure.

The non-abelian group of order 10 is the dihedral group D_5, which can be represented as the set of symmetries of a regular pentagon. D_5 has two generators, r and s, where r is a rotation by 72 degrees and s is a reflection. The relations between these generators are r^5 = s^2 = e (the identity element) and sr = r^(-1)s.

Now, let's analyze the structure of G using the given Cayley table. We can see that the element 'a' has order 5 (a^5 = e) and the element 'b' has order 2 (b^2 = e). We will try to find an element in G that satisfies the relation similar to sr = r^(-1)s in D_5.

Consider the product 'ba' in G, which is equal to 'i'. Now, let's compute the product 'abi' (which corresponds to sr^(-1)s in D_5). From the Cayley table, we have:

abi = (ba)(ai) = i(j) = c

Now, let's compute the inverse of 'a', which is a^4 (since a^5 = e). We have:

a^4 = c

This shows that the relation 'abi = a^(-1)' holds in G, similar to the relation sr = r^(-1)s in D_5.

Now, we can define a mapping φ: G → D_5 as follows:

φ(e) = e
φ(a) = r
φ(b) = s
φ(a^i) = r^i
φ(ba^i) = sr^i

This mapping is well-defined, as the relations between the elements in G match the relations between the corresponding elements in D_5. Furthermore, φ is a bijection, as it maps each element in G to a unique element in D_5 and vice versa.

Since φ is a bijective homomorphism, G is isomorphic to D_5, which is the non-abelian group of order 10.
